BiblioData.Title: AL(X)GA(1-X)N- CLADDING-FREE NONPOLAR III- NITRIDE BASED LASER DIODES AND LIGHT EMITTING DIODES

Applicant.Name: UNIV CALIFORNIA [US]
THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA

BiblioData.Abstract: A method for fabricating AlxGa1-xN-cladding-free nonpolar III-nitride based laser diodes or light emitting diodes. Due to the absence of polarization fields in the nonpolar crystal planes, these nonpolar devices have thick quantum wells that function as an optical waveguide to effectively confine the optical mode to the active region and eliminate the need for Al-containing waveguide cladding layers.

Claims.P: What is claimed is:
1. An optoelectronic device, comprising:
a nonpolar III-nitride semiconductor light emitting device having at least one nonpolar III-nitride quantum well with a thickness of at least 4 nanometers.
2. The device of claim 1, wherein the nonpolar III-nitride quantum well has a thickness greater than 4, 5, 6, 7, or 8 nanometers.

3. The device of claim 1, wherein a nonpolar III-nitride quantum well with a thickness of at least 4 nanometers provides greater optical confinement than a nonpolar III-nitride quantum well with a thickness of less than 4 nanometers.
4. The device of claim 1, wherein the nonpolar III-nitride quantum well active region provides sufficient optical confinement for the device's operation.
5. The device of claim 4, wherein the quantum well active region provides sufficient optical confinement for the device's operation in the absence of aluminum-containing cladding layers.
6. The device of claim 4, wherein the device includes aluminum-containing waveguide cladding layers with an aluminum content less than or equal to 10%.
7. The device of claim 4, wherein the device has aluminum-free waveguide cladding layers.
8. The device of claim 4, wherein the quantum well is an indium-containing quantum well.
9. The device of claim 4, wherein the quantum well active region functions as an optical waveguide for the device.
10. The device of claim 4, wherein the quantum well active region provides enough material with a high index of refraction to effectively confine an optical mode of the device.
11. The device of claim 1, wherein a substrate of the device does not have a substantial effect on the device's optical mode.
12. The device of claim 11, wherein a substrate of the device has an index of refraction lower than the quantum well active region.
13. The device of claim 1, wherein a nonpolar III-nitride is used as a substrate for the device.
14. The device of claim 1, wherein the device operates with a threshold current density less than 1 kA/cm<-2> .
15. A method of fabricating an optoelectronic device, comprising:
creating a nonpolar III-nitride semiconductor light emitting device having at least one nonpolar III-nitride quantum well with a thickness of at least 4 nanometers.
16. The method of claim 15, wherein the nonpolar III-nitride quantum well has a thickness greater than 4, 5, 6, 7, or 8 nanometers.

17. The method of claim 15, wherein a nonpolar III-nitride quantum well with a thickness of at least 4 nanometers provides greater optical confinement than a nonpolar III-nitride quantum well with a thickness of less than 4 nanometers.
18. The method of claim 15, wherein the nonpolar III-nitride quantum well active region provides sufficient optical confinement for the device's operation.
19. The method of claim 18, wherein the quantum well active region provides sufficient optical confinement for the device's operation in the absence of aluminum-containing cladding layers.
20. The method of claim 18, wherein the device includes aluminum-containing waveguide cladding layers with an aluminum content less than or equal to 10%.
21. The method of claim 18, wherein the device has aluminum-free waveguide cladding layers.
22. The method of claim 18, wherein the quantum well is an indium-containing quantum well.
23. The method of claim 18, wherein the quantum well active region functions as an optical waveguide for the device.
24. The method of claim 18, wherein the quantum well active region provides enough material with a high index of refraction to effectively confine an optical mode of the device.
25. The method of claim 15, wherein a substrate of the device does not have a substantial effect on the device's optical mode.
26. The method of claim 15, wherein a substrate of the device has an index of refraction lower than the quantum well active region.
27. The method of claim 15, wherein a nonpolar III-nitride is used as a substrate for the device.
28. The method of claim 15, wherein the device operates with a threshold current density less than 1 kA/cm<-2> .
